tn.text: "This is what Yahweh declares" or "This is Yahweh's message"

Here "Valley" refers to those who live in the valley, that is, Jerusalem. AT: "about those who live in the Valley of Vision" or "about those who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What is the reason that you have all gone up to the housetops?
tn.text: Isaiah uses a question to scold the people of Judah. AT: "You should not go and stand on the tops of your houses." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"a town full of people celebrating"

tn.ref: Your dead were not killed with the sword
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Enemy soldiers did not kill your people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "sword" represents the soldiers who fight in battle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but they were caught without a bow
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but the enemy caught your rulers who were not even carrying a bow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: all of them were caught and captured together
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the enemy caught and captured all of them together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "I" refers to Isaiah.

tn.ref: of the daughter of my people
tn.text: Here "daughter" represents the people and may imply Isaiah's feeling of love for them. AT: "of my people whom I love" or "of my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "day" refers to a longer period of time. AT: "For there will be a time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: of tumult, treading down, and confusion for the Lord, Yahweh of hosts
tn.text: "when Yahweh of hosts will cause panic, treading down, and confusion"
Possible meanings are 1) this refers to soldiers marching or 2) people in general are running in panic and not sure where to go.
This refers to Jerusalem. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:22:01|22:1]].

tn.ref: people crying out to the mountains
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "people in the mountains will hear their cries" or 2) "the people's cries will echo off the mountains"
The quiver is a bag to carry arrows and represents the archer's weapons. AT: "The soldiers of Elam take their bows and arrows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Kir" represents the soldiers. AT: "the soldiers of Kir will take their shields out of their covers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Kir is a city in Media. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "your" refers to the people of Jerusalem. Isaiah does include himself as one of the people of Jerusalem. AT: "our best valleys"

Isaiah continues to describe a time in the future when an army will attack the people of Jerusalem. Past tense verbs can be translated with future tense verbs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])

tn.ref: He took away the protection of Judah
tn.text: The abstract noun "protection" can be stated as a verb. AT: "Yahweh will take away everything that has protected the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: you looked in that day to the weapons
tn.text: Here the phrase "to look to" means to trust in something. AT: "to defend yourselves you will get the weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was a part of the temple in Jerusalem where they stored their weapons.

tn.ref: you collected the water of the lower pool
tn.text: The people will store water so that they will have enough to drink while their enemies surround the city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Isaiah continues to describe a time in the future when an army will attack the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
Here "counted" means they inspected the houses to find material to help them rebuild the city wall.
"You made a storage place"
It is unclear what two walls Isaiah meant. The main point is that they built the reservoir within the city walls.
This refers to Yahweh.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:09|1:9]].
This was a sign of mourning and repenting. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die
tn.text: Here "eat and drink" represents having a party and over indulging in food and wine. AT: "we may as well have fun now by eating and drinking all we want, for we will die soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: This was revealed in my ears by Yahweh of hosts
tn.text: Here "ears" represents Isaiah as a whole. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh of hosts revealed this to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Surely this iniquity will not be forgiven you, even when you die
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Surely I will not forgive you for these sinful things you have done, even when you die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh will never forgive them, even after they die or 2) Yahweh will not forgive them until they die.
This is the name of the manager of the king's palace in Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "house" represents those in the king's palace. AT: "who is in charge of all those who work in the palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What are you doing here and who gave you permission ... in the rock?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to scold Shebna. AT: "You have no right ... in the rock!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: cut out a tomb ... hewing out a grave ... carving out a resting place
tn.text: These three phrases all refer to making a burial tomb. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The most important people in Israel had tombs in the highest places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Isaiah continues to speak God's message to Shebna.

tn.ref: He will surely wind you round and round, and toss you like a ball into a vast country
tn.text: The enemy soldiers coming and taking Shebna as a captive to a foreign land is spoken of as if Yahweh were throwing him like a ball into another land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will be the shame of your master's house
tn.text: Here "house" represents the people who work in the king's palace. AT: "you will cause shame for all those in your master's palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will thrust you from your office and from your station. You will be pulled down
tn.text: Yahweh causing Shebna to no longer work in the king's palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will throw him to the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will bring you down from your honored position" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Isaiah continues to speak God's message to Shebna.

tn.ref: It will come about on that day
tn.text: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "It will happen at that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: I will clothe him with your tunic and put on him your sash
tn.text: Yahweh causing Eliakim to take Shebna's place in the king's palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will dress Eliakim in Shebna's clothes that represent his authority in the king's palace. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the tunic and sash represent authority in the king's palace. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a piece of cloth that people wear around the waist or across the chest. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:03:18|3:20]].
Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Eliakim caring for and protecting the people of Judah is spoken of as if he would be their father. AT: "He will be like a father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "house" represents the people. AT: "to the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will place the key of the house of David on his shoulder ... none will open
tn.text: Here "key" represents authority. This speaks of Eliakim having authority that no one can oppose as if he had the key to the palace and no one else could lock or unlock the door. AT: "I will put him in charge of those who work in the king's palace, and when he makes a decision no one will be able to oppose him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues to describe Eliakim, who will replace Shebna in the king's palace.

tn.ref: I will fasten him, a peg in a secure place
tn.text: Yahweh causing Eliakim's authority to be strong and secure in the king's palace is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg and Yahweh will set him firmly in the palace wall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he will become a seat of glory for his father's house
tn.text: Here "seat of glory" represents a place of honor. AT: "Eliakim will bring honor to his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "house" represents family. AT: "his father's family" or "his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They will hang on him all the glory of his father's house
tn.text: Yahweh causing Eliakim's whole family to be honored because of Eliakim is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg in the wall and his family were something that hangs on the peg. AT: "They will give honor to his whole family because of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: every small container from the cups to all the jugs
tn.text: This continues to speak of Eliakim as a peg. His offspring will be like cups that hang on the peg. This means his descendants will be honored because of him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the cups to all the jugs
tn.text: A cup is a small container that holds water. A jug is a larger container that holds water.
This continues the imagery from the previous verses. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:22:23|22:23-24]])
Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]].

tn.ref: the peg driven in a firm place ... will be cut off
tn.text: Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his authority in the king's palace is spoken of as if Shebna were a peg in the wall that breaks off and falls to the ground. This emphasizes that Shebna thought his authority was secure but God will remove him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the weight that was on it will be cut off
tn.text: Here "weight" represents Shebna's power and authority. It is spoken of as if it were an object hanging on the peg that represents Shebna. Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his power and authority is spoken of as if someone were to cut off the object that was hanging on the peg. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
